title: Mainpage
text: During my research journey in graduate school (MS and Ph.D. in Applied Economics), I developed a deep interest in Econometrics, Price Analysis, and Statistical Learning. This collection of essays showcases how I built my foundational knowledge and expanded my research focus. Please enjoy this material and feel free to contact me at jaeseok2@illinois.edu.

title: Jaeseok Hwang
Quantitative Risk Portfolio
text:
Jaeseok Hwang


Email · GitHub · LinkedIn


PhD Quantitative Economist (May 2026) focused on model validation, stress testing, and decision-risk diagnostics under non-stationarity. Open to finance risk analytics, model validation, and quantitative decision-science roles.


Built reproducible Python/R/SQL pipelines over 500k+ observations.


Designed out-of-group holdout diagnostics to test transferability risk.


Converted model error into decision-loss and deployment-governance signals.


Available to start: May 2026

title: Jaeseok Hwang
text:
Hi, I’m Jaeseok Hwang, a Ph.D. candidate in Agricultural and Consumer Economics (ACE)  at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC), with an expected graduation in May 2025. Over the past 5 years, I have gained extensive experience as a research assistant for the USDA NRCS-funded project, “Data Intensive Farm Management.” 
In this role, I worked extensively with large-scale datasets, applying advanced data analytics and statistical techniques to address complex questions in farm management and productivity. During this time, I developed a deep expertise in designing and running machine-learning-based regression models to derive actionable insights from big data. My analytical toolkit includes a professional level of proficiency in R, which I use for most of my data processing, statistical modeling, and visualization tasks, as well as Python, which I employ as a versatile second option for complementary analysis and machine learning workflows.
This website highlights my research journey, showcasing programming code (R and Python via VS Code), summary of research outputs, and my individual research note reflecting my knowledge and skills.
